Prompt: At the end of each day, close your computer and PUT IT AWAY. By fully disconnecting from work, you'll have a more restful evening‚Äîand a better day tomorrow.
Make your working hours clear to your housemates to save conflict later‚Äîyou can even display them on the fridge. "Cool" idea no? ü•∂üòâ"
Kids? Make a childcare schedule‚Äîand tell your colleagues when you'll be busy "circling back" to the crayon explosion in the living room.
Good boundaries = good housemates. Create separate productivity zones in different parts of the house so you don't distract each other.
Limited space? To minimize working from bed‚Äîtoo cozy, must nap!!‚Äîmake a schedule with housemates to share the living room.
Leaf darkness behind: like plants, humans need natural light! Set up your workstation near a window. Tell us if you learn to photosynthesize! üå±üòâ

Research shows the optimal room temperature for focused work is between 70-77F degrees; for most, 71F is ideal. üë©‚Äçüî¨ Productivity‚Äîbut make it SCIENCE. (Source: Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory)

For an ergo-friendly WFH workstation, your screen should be eye level and an arm's length away. Keyboard should allow for 90-degree bend of your arms (aka, your hands at or below elbow level). While seated, your knees should be level with your hips with both feet on the ground. Your bod will thank you!
If possible, invest in an ergo-friendly chair to prevent neck/back strain. If we gotta WFH, let's make it cozy. üòä
Try adding pictures of family and friends, flowers, and colors you love to your workspace‚ÄîWFH with joy.

Add a plant to your workstation. Research shows that greenery can help reduce stress‚Äîyour colleagues on videocalls will be green with envy. üò¨(Source: National Center for Biotechnology Information)
Schedule a 5-minute stretch break. You'll feel better, and the emails will still be there when you get back‚ÄîAND you'll be a limber profesh rockstar.
Super simple‚Äîand yet WEIRDLY easy to forget. If you‚Äôre struggling with mindless snacking while WFH, stop and ask yourself, ‚ÄúAm I hungry?‚Äù
Craving something sweet after a meal? Try a few squares of dark chocolate, a handful of frozen grapes, or‚Äîwait for it‚Äîa delish Light + Fit nonfat yogurt. üòâ
Don‚Äôt have weights at home? Try using canned goods, a laundry detergent container, or filling a milk jug with water. Fitness, bb.
Thinking about dinner already? Try working in foods thought to be good for your brain: walnuts, dark leafy greens, olive oil, dark chocolate, avocado, and fatty fish like salmon, tuna, and mackerel.
Incorporate fish at least 2x a week‚Äîsay, smoked salmon for breakfast, tuna for lunch. It's good for the brain (and the taste buds). üòã
Go meat-free one day a week‚Äîcall it Meatless Monday for cuteness points. Instead of meat, try tofu, beans/legumes, yogurt, nuts/seeds/nut butter, seitan, eggs, quinoa, etc.
Schedule a daily video-chat workout with your team‚Äîmaybe squats, pushups, jumping jacks, etc. Did someone say Squat Challange at noon?
Bored of regs water? Try infusing your water with fresh fruit, cucumber or lemon/lime. And of course, seltzer always adds an effervescent touch.
Not a veggie fan? Not a lover of greens? Try sneaking spinach into smoothies, adding veggies to your pasta or making butternut squash soup.

Keep essential oils at your desk. Lemon is said to keep you focused and calm, lavender to reduce tension and alleviate headaches, and cinnamon or peppermint for energy and concentration. You'll be an influencer before you know it.
Slumber struggs? Switch the screens on your mobile devices from blue light to orange light in the evenings to promote better sleep and circadian rhythms. (Source: Harvard Health)

WFH slug mode is real. The average American sits 12 hours a day, and that number has likely increased in recent days. Researchers recommend standing up every 20 minutes, standing for eight minutes, and moving for two minutes. (Source: Cornell University)
Schedule set times for meals & snacks. We're only human, but it is TECHNICALLY possible to avoid mindless grazing.

Meal planning can be a pain: knock it out before you get sucked into work mode! Every Sunday, brainstorm five healthy breakfasts, lunches, dinners and snacks that you can mix and match throughout the week.
Try to fill your plate with at least 50% fruits and/or vegetables at every meal for essential nutrients and belly-filling fiber.

Focus on balanced snacks that will fill you up, help balance your blood sugar and taste delicious. We're JUST SAYING: you could try Light + Fit nonfat yogurt with berries and trail mix. Or whole grain crackers and hummus. Either way.
No space for a home gym? (Those celebrities on Instagram are just rubbing it in, aren't they?) Try resistance bands, jump rope, ankle weights, or adjustable weights.

Want to become one of those happy morning workout people? Plan your workout the night before, sleep in clean workout clothes, and place your alarm away from your bed so you have to physically get out of bed to turn it off. Then all you have to do is get up and go in the morning!

Not getting enough sleep can trigger your hunger hormone (ghrelin) to increase, and a hormone associated with feeling full (leptin) to decrease. It's all connected, which means get those 7-8 hrs of sleep in as often as you can!
Time to sign off! Step away from your computer. Relax.
We know about two things in this world: 1. Yogurt 2. It's the end of the work day, friends. Wrap it up!
WFH can mean accidentally endless work days. Don't make today one of those days, wrap it up!
Productivity is great, but you need a break sometimes. Like right now. It's EOD, close your laptop!
If someone is bugging you for work right now, Slack them that it's EOD and you're done. You can tell them yogurt sent you.
Taking advice from yogurt might not ALWAYS be smart, but we're pretty sure about this one: it's the end of the day. You're done, go chill!
What show are you going to watch tonight? Get thinking, it's almost time to close that laptop!
Working is important‚Äîwe all gotta do it. But if you work all night, you will be sad. Don't work all night. It's EOD, you're done, go celebrate a productive day!
Working all evening is like trying to punch a bear: you MIGHT succeed, but even if you do... think of the cost. It's EOD, you can be done now.
Congratulations, you've successfully navigated another day of WFH! Time to step away from the computer.
WFH successfully means setting clear boundaries. Here's a boundary for you: it's EOD, start to wrap it up!
In the nicest way possible: It's time for you to stop working. Right now. No really right now, you can be done.
Stop working, yogurt fans. You're done! EOD! Woo!
One thing we love about WFH: short distance from desk to couch. It's couch time, folks.
In case you needed a little loving encouragement: it's EOD! Stop working! You're killing it. Now it's time to relax.
Hey you, it's nearing EOD - time to wrap it up. Your puzzle, book or next Netflix epsiode are counting on you!

Part of your WFH wellness routine should be setting work hour boundaries. Sure, you may have a late night here or there, but don't make it a habit. Now more than ever, give yourself a break, and that puzzle you're working on some love.

Maintaining a consistent evening routine signals to your body that it‚Äôs time to start shutting down. 30 minutes before bed, try turning off electronics, dimming the lights, drinking some herbal tea or reading a book. It's the beauty rest express.

If you're waking up in the middle of the night with your to-do list running through your head, keep a notepad next to your bed and write down whatever's bugging you. It can be surprisingly helpful for getting back to the restful sleep you need!
WFH slug mode is real. Schedule a few minutes every day for self-care‚Äîwhether that be skin care, makeup, hair, whatever you prefer.

It's the best time ever to organize your inbox. Unsubscribe from mediocre mailing lists, create folder systems, ask to be removed from cc if you don‚Äôt need to participate, color code emails based on importance and delete anything you don‚Äôt need. Be ruthless‚Äîa clean inbox is an amazing feeling.
Feeling stir crazy while stuck inside? Change your computer desktop photo to nature or a favorite destination you‚Äôd like to visit once this passes.
Download a meditation app: research shows that just a few days of meditation can help improve concentration/focus and reduce anxiety/stress.

Ask HR or your insurance carrier about telehealth services offered as part of your company benefits. You may be able to speak with a therapist, dietitian, physician, fitness specialist, financial planner etc. from your home for free.

Come up with a mantra or affirmation to use whenever you start feeling stressed or down. ‚ÄúI am calm and at peace‚Äù; ‚ÄúI radiate good health‚Äù; ‚ÄúI will focus only on what I can control‚Äù; "I am obsessed with Light + Fit yogurt." We're kidding about the last one... or are we...

Take it easy on yourself. Some days you may check off everything on your to-do list and feel like a rockstar. Other days you may spend all day putting out unexpected fires or getting distracted by nonsense. It happens to the best of us. Clich√©d but true: tomorrow is in fact a new day.
Here's the thing, it's okay to just be, sit, think, breathe, relax. Some days you need rest more than others.
Stay connected with your coworkers by sharing your favorite healthy tips (recipes, meal prep, workouts etc.)‚Äîthis is the time to support each other!!

Autopilot is real: try taking inventory of how you‚Äôre feeling. If you notice you feel anxious on days you drink five cups of coffee and have the news on TV all day, switching up some of those habits might make you feel a lot better.
Try deep breathing exercises at your workstation. Inhale and count to 5, exhale and count to 5. Repeat 5-10 times. It's magic, tbh.
Figure out the best times in your schedule for certain tasks. Are you too tired at the end of the day to exercise? Then ~get your sweat on~ first thing in the morning.
Take a lunch break away from your desk: stretch, eat near a window, chill for a second. YOU DESERVE IT.

Get showered and dressed for the day, even if you don‚Äôt have any videocalls. It's weirdly effective at tricking your mind into feeling alert and productive. Even if you only get jeans on one day a week, that's okay!
Put your phone on airplane mode during dedicated work time so you don‚Äôt get distracted. We're looking at you, dating apps, social media, and... "everything."

Taking breaks can boost productivity and focus. Even short ones! Studies show that watching a funny 8-minute video or spending less than 1 minute looking at nature improves employee performance when they return to their work task.

Chaotic energy not working for you these days? Practice time blocking. Each time block is dedicated to accomplishing a specific task/group of tasks. Instead of keeping an open-ended to-do list of things you‚Äôll get to as you‚Äôre able, you‚Äôll start each day with a concrete schedule that lays out what you‚Äôll work on and when.
Hey, have you taken a deep breath yet today?
5 minute break: clean up your desk or change up where you're working from at home. Breathe some new inspiration into your day!
Your work bestie misses you (yes, they told us). Schedule a virtual coffee date soon. ‚òï
Fill a 32 fl oz water bottle first thing in the morning. Set a goal to drink bottle #1 before noon, refill at lunchtime, and fill your 2nd bottle to finish by 6pm. #WATER
Here's the thing about drinking water: do it.
Hydration is key. Don't NOT do it, you know what we're saying? #drink #water #doit
Reminder: water. Drink it, okay? Now's a good time.
Hey, your body called. We let it go to voicemail because, weird, but it says: it wants you to drink water.
Drinking water is great for many reasons, among them: feeling good, being hydrated, feeling great, hydration.
Hey, are you drinking water right now? Okay liar, lol. #drinkwater
We may love yogurt, but we also love water. What do you love? Your body told us water, drink some water.
Water: drink it.
Did you hear that one joke about the water that someone drank? It was a good one because it reminded us to hydrate. Drink water.
Water: tastes good, feels good, is good. #water #drinkit
Ever wonder why water is so great? We suggest experiential learning to find out. #drinkwater
Stay hydrated while WFH. Drink water. Like maybe right now?

A consistent morning routine goes a long way. Healthy breakfast, exercise, meditation, coffee, reading a book‚Äîwhatever feels best for you. Why? Because rolling out of bed two minutes before your first meeting is a recipe for pain.
Make your bed first thing in the morning‚Äîunfortunately, your parents were right about this one. Surveys show it really does foster a more productive day. (Source: National Sleep Foundation)
Start your day with a balanced breakfast. Try yogurt with berries and cereal or a veggie filled omelete with toast. Oatmeal with a scoop of nut butter and chopped apples is a great option too!

Missing your daily coffee shop run? Try a DIY latte. Heat ¬Ω cup milk (dairy or non-dairy) for 45 seconds in the microwave. When done, use a small whisk or frother for 20 seconds. Pour coffee over frothed milk and enjoy. You can even spell your name wrong on the cup for extra authenticity.

Bake some better-for-you muffins for breakfast or a midday snack. Swap oil for half the amount of yogurt to save calories and fat (ex: 1 cup oil = ¬Ω cup yogurt). You could even offer some to your roommates‚Äîor use them as a bargaining chip to gain control over Netflix. üòà

When the coffee is now within arms reach, make sure you're not overdoing it on the caffeine. Aim for 2 coffees or less per day. If you love the ritual of an afternoon brew, try switching to decaf or tea to avoid getting the jitters.
Replace your commute time with anything you've wished you had more time for: workouts, fam time, reading a great book, even sleeping in! Tell the haters we gave you permish.
If you're visually oriented, try keeping a paper calendar or sticker chart posted above your workspace or fridge to stay on top of your goals‚Äîlike meditating, exercising, or eating well.
Put healthy foods front and center in your kitchen. You‚Äôll be more likely to reach for them if these foods are located in a prominent place. We are INCENTIVIZING WELLNESS OUT HERE, FOLKS, NBD.
Wash and slice vegetables as soon as you bring them home to make them easier to grab for snacks. You'll be doing your future self a favor.
Try scheduling a workout into your calendar and prioritizing it like an important work meeting you wouldn‚Äôt miss. THAT "meeting" won't have "next steps" or "action items"! Showering, maybe.
Every hour or every other hour, get up and do 10 jumping jacks, 10 squats, 10 pushups and 10 sit ups. If you work an 8-hour day, that‚Äôs 80 reps of each exercise! Fit city, population you.

You're the boss of your wellness. Create your own 7-minute workout: write out 7 body-weight exercises to do for 1 minute each (ex: pushups, situps, squats, crunches, mountain climbers, chair tricep dips, burpees, jog in place, jumping jacks, planks). Now get to it!
If you have a step tracker device, start a virtual walking challenge with your coworkers. Hannah might get paid more than you, but she's about to get ~crushed~ on this one.
Try a 30-day plank challenge. Just be careful you don't reignite the "planking" meme. That's the last thing we need.

Find an accountability partner (coworker, friend, roommate, etc.) and set 1-3 healthy goals for each day, then check in at the end of each day to report back. Harness your competitive spirit for a healthy cause!

Prep your healthy lunches for the week in advance (ex: quinoa salad, turkey chili, grilled chicken and avocado wrap)‚Äîthat way you can free your mind to concentrate on things like work, family, and the very spiciest memes.

Step away from your workstation for meals/snacks and take time to savor every bite. Eating while distracted can lead to overeating and lower satisfaction. And let's be real: screen breaks are more important than ever.

Don‚Äôt be afraid of frozen fruits and vegetables. They are frozen at their peak freshness, so they retain all of their nutrients and are just as healthy‚ÄîAND they're great for smoothies. Ya know, for when it's smoothie o'clock.
Start a Pinterest board to save snack and meal ideas for inspo during weekly meal prep. You can ALSO use Pinterest for party-decor ideas for when social distancing is over!
On a work call? Try walking around your house/apartment to get some extra steps in.

Spending more time in the kitchen these days? Try cooking one new healthy recipe this week. Keep it up each week and by the end of the year, you‚Äôll have 25-50 new recipes to choose from! Everyone on Instagram will be *incredibly* jealous.
Create your own single serving snacks for easy portion control (instead of eating straight from the bag). We all have our moments!
Cooking more these days but don‚Äôt love leftovers? SPICE EM UP! Take that leftover chicken from last night and use it for a delish stir fry.
Hey you, take a 10-minute break from work and create an at-home workout video playlist on YouTube with your favorite free workouts. Internet procrastination CAN be useful.
Virtual dance party, GO. Your living room IS NOW THE DANCE FLOOR. Fully optional: inviting roommates, family, or colleagues online.
Aim for 7-8 hours of sleep per night. We know, you've heard it a million times. But this one is important!!! (Ya know, if you like "feeling good.")

Think about the random conversations you‚Äôd have around the office that can't happen while WFH‚Äîtry to reach out to people more, even about non-work topics! We all need a fulfilling social diet‚Äînow more than ever.
Choose a relaxing and uplifting playlist to listen to while working. That way, when someone Slacks you "vibe check," you can report that the vibes are excellent.

This is a stressful time. Stay grounded by writing a list of three things you‚Äôre grateful for every morning‚Äîor share them on a small group text with friends. Might feel cheesy, but trust us, it'll feel good.
